Ottawa, November 6, 1947.

Dear Sirs:

We have just received the following letter in connection with our Fort Frances Indian Residential School:

"The oven at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School has burned out and the local tinsmith will not attempt to dismantle same until he sees a blue print. This oven was made by the Pendroth Machine Co., 775 West King Street Toronto and the serial number is 1177.

"In view of the urgency as the school cannot bake bread will you kindly forward a blue print together with the necessary authority to have the repair done and oblige."

I would appreciate it if you would forward me a blue print of this machine at the earliest possible date.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare - Training.

Messrs. Pendroth Machine Co.,
775 West King St.,
Toronto, Ontario.

PP/MGD
Pendrith Machinery Co. Limited

Manufacturers and Importers of

Dear Sir:-

Re your 124 - 1 - 5 (WT 1)

Replying to yours of the 6th inst. in connection with
oven at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

This oven, sold by us Oct. 1930, is our #12 as illus-
trated in enclosed bulletin. The illustration on page 1009 of
this bulletin, which shows the same type of oven partly taken

to supply same.

Yours very truly,

Pendrith Machinery Co. Limited

Per. R.G. Carpenter
EX'D.

Ottawa, November 12, 1947.

Mr. J.F. Lockhart, Indian Agent,
Fort Frances, Ontario.

Upon receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo concerning the oven at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School, we immediately wrote the manufacturer, Pendreth Machine Co.

We are now in receipt of the enclosed bulletin which you require. For your information, the Company's letter reads in part as follows:

"This oven sold by us Oct. 1930, is our #12 as illustrated in enclosed bulletin. The illustration on page 1009 of this bulletin, which shows the same type of oven partly taken down, will indicate to the local tinsmith how this oven was set up and how the sections can be taken down."

Bernard A. Henry
Sept. of Welfare & Training.

Attached please find statement from A.J. Westell, Fort Frances, covering electrical work done at the Residential School.

Father de Varennes, newly appointed Principal at the school, has requested that I forward this account for the Department's consideration.

Ottawa, November 16, 1947.

Mr. J.F. Lockhart, Indian Agent,
Fort Frances, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 12th instant enclosing the attached account covering electrical work done at the Fort Frances Residential School.

As the new stove only reached the school during the month of September, it is difficult for the Department to understand why it should have been necessary to spend such a large amount on it within such a short time.

Please let me have a full explanation of the matter and at the same time you may return the attached account on proper voucher form. When we receive your explanation and the account, we will decide if the Department should make any payment.

Incidentally, I might point out that one item on the account reads "Labour 12 hours, 2 men - $36.00". This item should show the exact dates and the number of hours each man was employed and the rate per hour for each of them.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Fort Frances, Ont., Nov. 17, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

When visiting the Residential School I found 51 pupils in the Junior Classroom and there is not sufficient seats for this number. Some children were sitting on wooden blocks which gives no support to the back and their posture is out of line for writing.

The front row of seats cannot be used as there are no desks, and I would like to request the immediate purchase of 6 single desks (only) No. 5, then the back row can be moved forward. There is one row of double seats holding 16 pupils which should be replaced at a future date, but for this year the 6 mentioned above are urgently needed.

May I be favoured with an early reply, and oblige.

J. F. Lockhart,
Indian Agent.

Fort Frances, Ont., November 28, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I wish to report that I have made a complete check on fire fighting equipment at the Fort Frances Residential School and found same to be in very poor condition. It must have been years since hose was supplied as it has deteriorated and is now unable to stand any pressure.

At present there are only 12 Pyrene Extinguishers in working condition, and 15 Dry Powder Fire Extinguishers.

I also found that fire drill has not been carried out and have suggested that a practice should be held each week.

I am attaching a list of material which I would recommend if funds permit.

J. F. Lockhart,
Indian Agent.

Encl.

Memorandum:

Re: Water Supply - Fort Frances Indian Residential School, Ontario.

Further to our memorandum of November 15th, 1947, in which we forwarded triplicate copies of the Agreement between the Township Council of the Town of Fort Frances and the Department, we asked Mr. Gow for a statement accompanied by a sketch to give information as to the work which had been done by the Town of Fort Frances.

You will note from the following quotation from a letter dated November 31st from Mr. Gow that he is not able to give us the detailed information we would like to have. His letter reads as follows:

"We have for attention your letter of the 14th instant in connection with the extension of the Fort Frances water supply to the Indian School. Your request for a full report and detailed plan of the installation has been noted.

Under date of August 5 last we forwarded a memorandum by Mr. J.T. Ross, of this staff and a print from a plot made by Mr. D.J. Gibson, D.M.S., dated November 24, 1946 and entitled "Map of Indian Reserve No. 1, Rainy Lake District Rainy River". I would refer you to this correspondence so that you may understand the difficulty in providing a detailed plan that can be accurately used to show locations of this pipe line as actually constructed. This print did not cover the land operated by the Indian School and so far as we can learn, no plan exists at Fort Frances although it is possible that such a plan is available in the Indian Affairs Branch. The actual construction of the line and connection to the school was carried out by the Town of Fort Frances without supervision from this office inasmuch as the Town is by agreement held responsible for the maintenance of the water line. We can, of course, secure from the town a description of the method of construction and what material was put into the job. However, the town has no engineer and I do not believe have any plans showing the construction. To give all the details asked for in your letter would involve a considerable amount of survey work in the field by this office and we are not in a position to do this until next summer.

By the terms of the agreement, which is now awaiting signature at Ottawa, the Town of Fort Frances undertook to carry out certain work and accept certain responsibilities. This work has been completed and they have assumed these responsibilities. The responsibility of the Indian Affairs Branch was to contribute $6,000.00 towards this work; presumably before the work was instituted. I could ask, therefore, that there be no further delay in connection with the payment to the Town of Fort Frances."

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director, Lands & Development Services Branch,
Horlitz Building, OTTAWA.

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this second day of December, 1947.

THE PARTIES:

HIS MAJESTY THE KING, represented by the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources, hereinafter called "His Majesty"

OF THE FIRST PART

AND

THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF FORT FRANCES, Province of Ontario,

OF THE SECOND PART.

WHEREAS the Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances, by virtue of an agreement with the Corporation of the Township of Neirvine, has installed a water main to the Indian Residential School situated on the shore of Sand Bay, Rainy Lake, near the said town and in the said township;

AND WHEREAS the said installation is for the purpose of supplying water to the said Indian Residential School His Majesty has agreed to pay to the said Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances the sum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00)

NOW, THEREFORE, THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that the parties hereto agree, each with the other, as follows:

1. That the Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances shall maintain the water main so constructed and subject to conditions beyond its control will supply water to the said Indian Residential School.

2. That the Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances shall have the right to charge and collect in accordance with its bylaws and regulations for water so supplied at the rate of $1.00 per thousand gallons and pending installation of a water meter a charge of One Dollar ($1.00) per day shall be made for the said service.
3. That the Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances shall supply, free of charge, at all times, necessary fire fighting equipment and personnel to fight and extinguish any fires which may occur at any time in or to the said Indian Residential School. Water used to extinguish fires and obtained from the fire hydrant installed near the said Indian Residential School shall be supplied free of charge.

4. That His Majesty shall supply a three-inch water meter approved by the Superintendent of Water Works System of the said Corporation for measurement of the said service, which shall be installed by the Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have hereunto set their hands, the Party of the Second Part affixing its Corporate Seal by the hands of its proper officers.

Memorandum:

Re: Fort Frances Indian Residential School,
Fort Frances, Ontario,

In September 1945, the Lands and Development Service, formerly Surveys and Engineering Branch, submitted a report on the water situation at the above mentioned school.

The school was obtaining its water from an adjacent lake but a report indicated that it was dangerous to continue this procedure as the water in this lake was becoming contaminated.

Our Engineers learned that the Town of Fort Frances intended to extend their water main to Tourist Park and located farther from the Town than the Fort Frances Residential School.

The Town authorities proposed to our Engineers that if the Department would provide an amount of $6,000.00 towards the cost of installing the new line, they would be prepared to supply water to Fort Frances Residential School at reasonable cost.

The Surveys and Engineering Branch expressed the opinion that the amount requested by the Town of Fort Frances was reasonable and it was the best manner in which we could secure a dependable supply.

Replying to your letter of the 18th ultimo regarding the enclosed account, I wish to point out that when the new electrical stove was installed at the school it was found that the house load was not sufficient to operate the stove. Father Chatelain, former Principal, called in A.J. Webster, local electrician, and they decided to put in a new independent service from outside the building and installed a separate meter.

There was nothing wrong with the new stove supplied and the fault lay in not determining the load on the service, which, with added meters etc. since the line was installed, had overtaxed the load. The stove is now working satisfactory.

THAT it is considered advisable to provide a suitable water supply for the Fort Frances Indian Residential School in the Province of Ontario;

THAT the Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances is agreeable to extend its water main to the said school providing the cost of such installation, estimated to be six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) is paid by His Majesty;

THAT the engineers of the Department of Mines and Resources advise that the estimated cost of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) for this work is fair and just;

THAT the required amount of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) to pay for the said installation is available in Vote 153, 1947-48, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that he be granted authority to pay to the Corporation of the Town of Fort Frances in the Province of Ontario, the amount of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) the estimated cost for installing the water main to the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Fort Frances, Ont., January 6, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I wish to report that it has been necessary to do emergency repairs on the heating plant at the Residential School over the week-end.

The retort on the stoker has burned out as well as the motor and needs to be replaced. As the school was without heat it was necessary to engage a steam fitter to connect up the high pressure boiler, which is hand fired, and used in the laundry to the intake line of the school so that it would act as a stand-by until repairs can be made on the stoker. By doing this work it was not necessary to shut down the school.

A further report will be forwarded as soon as the total expense involved is determined.

Memorandum:

Re: Fort Frances Indian Residential School

Further to our memorandum of August 7th, 1947, in connection with repairs and revisions to the above, you are advised as follows:

Mr. Gow has personally contacted three contracting firms in Fort Frances. The North American Lumber Company, largest firm of its kind in the town, were unwilling to bid under any arrangement owing to former commitments and the uncertain labour situation. Another builder, not named, was indifferent and unimpressive; and it was felt unwise to attempt to negotiate with him.

The Smith Construction Company, successors to John East estate, offer to undertake the work on a cost plus tax per cent basis. They have carried out work at this school in the past under Mr. Gow's direction, and he has found them to be very reliable; consequently he requested them to submit an estimate to him which he will forward to us as soon as possible. In the meantime, we are forwarding to Mr. Gow for his information our own estimate of the cost of this work.

As a result of a more complete layout covering in particular revisions to the walk-in refrigerator, you are advised that approximately $700.00 must be added to our original estimate of $2,500. This means that Indian Affairs should be advised to provide about $3,200 for this work.

Mr. Smith of the Smith Construction Company, urged that an early decision be reached in order to enable him to plan for materials and labour. In the meantime, he has agreed to prepare an estimate and forward same to Mr. Gow who will pass it along to us. When we are in receipt of same you will be further advised.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum

Re: Fort Frances Indian Residential School,
Fort Frances, Ont.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of May 25th bearing your marginal notation of May 28th in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

Since the Principal of the school has found it impossible to take on the work outlined on our plans and specifications after having offered to do so, we again requested Mr. Gow to obtain competitive tenders.

After some difficulty and delay owing to business activity in this area, Mr. Gow was able to procure but one tender. This was submitted by Wellington Smith Limited of Fort Frances in the sum of $5,475.00 with electric wiring to be charged extra to this sum.

This price is considerably higher than the original rough estimate of $3,300.00 submitted by the P.H. Smith Company in October 1947. We have discussed the matter with Indian Affairs officials on the telephone and they have indicated their intention to proceed with the work on the basis of the tendered price.

While the price as stated is high, it is not considered exorbitant as there are of necessity, many uncertainties to be encountered in a job of this nature.

It is pointed out that the tender varies in one respect from the requirements called for on our design. The Wellington Smith Limited proposal to install a metal hood over the kitchen range to connect to the chimney using natural draught instead of an exhaust fan as called for. We do not concur with this suggestion as the movement of air required to ventilate this area cannot be obtained by natural draught. Further, it is against recognized principles to install a ventilating pipe and connect same to a chimney.

We are advised verbally that the Indian Affairs Branch will prepare a memorandum to Council requesting authority to have the work carried out for the above sum. They have requested that this Branch take on supervision of the project, which can conveniently be handled by Mr. Gow's office.

The Reserve at the foot of Rainy Lake, near Port Frances, in which is situated the 20 acres desired by His Grace Archbishop Langevin, for the purposes of a mission, was set apart by Mr. Tawson in 1876 in the following terms:

"No. 1. At the foot of Rainy Lake, to be laid off as nearly as may be in the manner indicated on the plan, two chains in depth along the shore of Rainy Lake and Bank of Rainy River to be reserved for roads, right of way for lumber men, homes, wharves, and other public purposes.

This Indian Reserve not to be for any particular Chief or Band, but for the Gauleaux Tribe generally, and for the purpose of maintaining thereon an Indian Agency, with the necessary grounds and buildings."

It would therefore appear that the consent of certain Tribes and Bands would be necessary before any portion of the Reserve may be used for any other purpose. Probably only the Rainy Lake and Rainy River Bands have been in the habit of making any use of this Reserve, and these may be the only Bands necessary to consult. The title not only of this Reserve, but I understand of all other Indian Reserves in what is called New Ontario is in an unsatisfactory state. Mining claims are likely soon to be applied for on some of them, and the cutting of timber on the reserves is under limitation owing to the same uncertainty of title.

From an educational standpoint it is considered difficult to conduct efficiently and effectively the St. Boniface Industrial School at the present per capita rate. The school as located does not afford facilities to train Indian boys in agriculture; but the Church authorities will undertake to have a man in charge of the boys at each of the proposed boarding schools and one at the school at Fort Relly who will teach them practical farming; and, with the boys taught to farm and the girls to do house work, the Department would have from the proposed schools more desirable educational results than can be hoped for from St. Boniface and thirty-two more Indian pupils will be benefitted by the proposed exchange. With reference to letters hereunder from Agent Wright and the Principal of the Fort Frances Indian Boarding school, I beg to state that on my recent visit to Fort Frances I visited the school. With reference to disposal of part of surrendered portion of Agency Indian Reserve No.1, Fort Frances, an Order in Council was passed 26th July, 1907 by the Province of Ontario giving consent to the surrender of Indian Reserves Nos. 1, 16A, 16B, 10, 11, 12, 13, 27, 14, 15 and the Wild Lands Reserve, all in the Rainy River District on or near Rainy River on condition that they be sold to actual settlers.

Further Orders in Council are necessary for the disposal in any other manner, and when part of the Agency Reserve was leased for park purposes to the Town of Fort Frances a new one dated the 4th September 1908 was passed.

As this reserve was surrendered by the Indians with a view to the land being sold by this Department for the benefit of the Indians and the consent of the province was given on condition that the land be sold to actual settlers, I am doubtful if additional land can be added to the school without compensation unless the consent of the province be obtained.

In view of a letter from the Department of Lands, Mines and Forests, dated 31st July 1916, File 204,596-2 regarding consent of the province to the issue of a patent to the Canadian Northern Railway, fault is found with the charging of a rental of one dollar per acre per year for that portion now leased for park purposes to the town of Fort Frances.

May 2, 1927.

The attached telegram from file 124-1-9 will explain my hurried departure for Fort Frances.

I had intended speaking to you before leaving for an interview I had, in my office, with the Rev. Father Superior of the Oblate Order for that District. While he was anxious that the school should have what land was necessary, he said he would be very pleased to have me call on him at Winnipeg after having gone over the situation at Fort Frances with a view to having a better understanding of the situation.

If you think I should not do this will you please wire me at Fort Frances on Thursday to return from there. I have taken transportation to Winnipeg in case you think I should go on, but refund can be obtained on the difference if not used, I presume.

It might be advisable to talk the matter over with the Father Superior and possibly the Archbishop of St. Boniface in order that they may have a clear understanding of the situation and the actual facts as to provision made for the school if I find that the 86 acres we are renting for them is good and sufficient land. However, I leave this to your judgment and if not instructed to the contrary, will presume you intend me to proceed to Winnipeg.

[Signature]

F. J. J. J.
"So far as cultivable land is concerned, the school has not yet cultivated all the acreage they own. While I am of the opinion that the school is well provided for in acreage, I would like very much to see them get that parcel adjoining the north boundary and containing about 12 acres. This is the parcel I have already referred to as being excellent soil as compared with their present holdings."

Mr. Parker recommends that we lease the 12 acres of Arnold (or Allan) for the use of the school and that the school clear the 88 acre plot (an inexpensive undertaking) so that the Fort Frances Golf Club be given a lease of the 20 acres they want and that he explain this to Archbishop Beliveau of St. Boniface.

MEMO FOR FILE:

The original of Mr. Parker's report of May 13th is on file 3228-2. In brief he states the school has 65 acres (43.2 acres with buildings and 20 acres to the southwest) and in addition, in 1916 (file 27124-2) 88.15 acres of reserve 16 was leased to the school for a period of 15 years. To quote:

"With the 65 acres forming the school lot proper, this gives a total available area of 151 acres. No promise was ever made of the 20 acres now in dispute and the provision of the 88 acres in 1916 was plainly intended as a settlement of the land question at Fort Frances Boarding School, and, furthermore, no further mention of the matter had been made until the letter previously referred to, in Oct., 1926, written after the Rev. Principal had heard that the 20 acres was likely to be leased to a Golf Club."

"After having examined this land, I paid some attention to a plot immediately north of the school lot and in Reserve 16A. This is an excellent piece of land and of superior soil to any other I examined while at Fort Frances. I think this plot would cover about 10-12 acres. It is owned by the band but I understand held by an Indian known as Fred Arnold, now in gaol. The land is only half cleared, the balance being covered with small undergrowth. The School is using the cleared portion under some agreement with Arnold."

"Of the school lands I found the original 43 acres all cleared and cultivated. On the 20 acre addition, I found it all cleared but about 5 acres in the south end not yet cleaned up and evidently never yet cultivated. In fact the entire 20 acre plot does not show signs of active cultivation."

"After having carefully viewed the matter from every standpoint, I am compelled to admit that the school having got along in the past with the allotted land can do so in the future. The only use ever made of the 88 acres was to pasture a few cows. The 65 acres to the north of the school will provide all the pasture they require and more. If they were to clear and fence a part of it, cattle could be pastured there from early summer on."

Dear Sir:

I am glad to learn that the Indian Department has the intention to give me a compensation for the school land leased to the Fort Frances Golf Club. It is for me a great relief which when the occurrence would come into effect would remove the thorn deeply thrust into my heart since the day of the negotiation of the lease. That compensation so long expected would always be welcome but especially at the coming Christmas.

The lot of the Indian reserve immediately N.W. of the school containing approximately 15 acres was owned by Fred Allan on the date of the lease. Since he left the school a few years ago he is always absent from the reserve; he comes back only once a year for a few days to get his treaty money. He has not made any improvements of any kind. He is consenting to dispose of his land in favor of the school, either renting or selling as you may see by the note he signed for the purpose and I have handed it to Revd Father I.Guy O.M.I. The reasons he gave me when making the paper was that he did not intend to ever use his land, and he would be pleased to help the school in remembrance of the education he received there. It would be preferable to buy than to rent the land, as the school could always need it all the time, and no more negotiations would be required in the future.

The price of the land could be set by the Indian Agent himself and the money of the sale should be deposited in the bank and handed to Fred Allan when he proves to make a good use of it, however if the note bearing his signature is not sufficient for the final dealing we have to wait for him at the next treaty payment.

Charles Jourdain is the owner of the next lot containing approximately 12 or 14 acres. He is a widower of 50 years old, has only one boy of 21 years old. He has a shack, a garden large enough to plant ½ a bushel of potatoes. The rest of his land is absolutely left vacant and unutilized. He would consent to sell the fraction of his land required to form the balance of 23 acres leased to the Golf Club at the price set by the Indian Agent, at any time I could get his signature for the formal dealing.

Hoping to have an early settlement,

Your obedient Servant,

To The Honorable D.C. Scott,
Deputy Supt. General,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

For the last 15 years, the Department has rented a tract of land on the Reserve, west of the railroad, for the use of the School. The lease expires on July 16th, 1931.

This land has served us wonderfully well as a pasture. There is abundant feed for what cattle we have, and being well tread, it is a protection against the intense heat of summer as well as against flies.

What land the School has besides the above mentioned tract, is barely sufficient for our winter supply of hay and oats, so that if we were to lose this rented land, we would be forced to use our own land for pasture and consequently buy all our feed for winter.

The School has already spent a fair amount for improvements on this land. Last year we had to put up a new fence, the old one having been destroyed by bush fire.

Furthermore this land is practically useless to the people of the Reserve, and will be so for quite a few years to come. Most homes are already built and a great number of these are at Frog Creek, about three miles from the School. We have, however offered those who wished it, to build their homes on the higher levels of this tract of land. There are a few good locations that would be well protected from rising waters in the spring, but so far none have accepted this offer, which gives further proof of the uselessness of this land to them.

Therefore, dear Sir, we would like to petition the Department to give Mr. Spencer necessary authority to renew the lease for an equal period of time. By so doing, the School will be assured of summer feed for the stock on this land and winter feed from our cultivated land.

Yours truly,

H.M. Brassard, O.M.I.

Principal.
November 21st, 1930.

MEMORANDUM:

P.C. 1818 of August 2nd, 1916, authorized the lease of 75 acres, more or less, of Indian reserve No. 16 A. This land has been used by the Fort Frances Indian Residential School. The property actually comprised 88.18 acres and School Vote has paid to the credit of the band (Account 130) annually, $88.18.

The Reverend Principal of the school is very desirous that this land be secured for school purposes for a further term. The school has many improvements on it and it is really needed for educational purposes. The question of paying rentals as during the past fifteen years is desirable. The school is maintained largely for the benefit of the children of this and neighbouring reserves. Why should not the parcel in question be surrendered for school purposes and no rental charged? This is the practice practically everywhere else in Canada. In any case, this land is needed for school purposes and I should be grateful if you would take whatever action you consider advisable.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE.
CALGARY, ALTA., October 30th, 1933.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that for the last year or so an Indian by the name of Fred Allen, No. 95 of the Couchiching Band in the Fort Frances Agency has been around this part of the country off and on. Part of the time before he has been on city relief here I have helped him out several times with food, and whenever he got work and earned any money he came in and paid his debts. He was in last August and was completely in rags, and I had to outfit him with some clothing, and he informed me that he had $15.00 yearly rental coming for land on the Couchiching Reserve. I wrote to Mr. Spencer, the Agent there, and he informs me that this is correct.

Would it be in order to render a voucher to the Department for supplies that Fred Allen received from the Hudson's Bay Company here on my order, so that this account can be paid? I shall be glad to be advised on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
November 6th, 1933.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 30th ultimo reporting that an Indian of the Couchiching Band was in destitute circumstances when in Calgary and that you gave him some assistance.

With reference to the rental of $15.00 which is payable to Fred Allen, the Indian referred to, I would say that this amount will be payable to him in December. You may forward the account in triplicate to the amount of $15.00 to Mr. Spencer, explaining the matter and asking him to submit vouchers to the Department to be paid from Allen's rental.

For your information I may say that this Indian, who gives his name as Fred Allen, is also known as Fred Jourdain and also as Fred Arnold.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

November 5th, 1933.

Sir—

A letter has been received from Mr. Christianson, Indian Inspector at Calgary, Alberta, that Fred Allen #95 of the Cochrane Band in your Agency, has called upon him for assistance. Mr. Christianson is being asked to send the account in triplicate to you and I would ask that you submit vouchers to the Department indicating that payment is to be made from rental due Allen.

June 9th, 1925.

To Honourable Duncan G Scott
Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Honourable Sir:

I wish to make some innovations in regard to
the herd of cattle of the Indian School of Fort Frances, Ont., which
no doubt you would approve.

It is my intention to reduce the number of
cows which is actually eleven, to five for the following reason:
The farm of the School is too small to keep more with profit.
Moreover, what would be the use to have a stock producing more milk
than could be consumed? No doubt five good milking cows would give
all the milk and butter needed for the pupils and staff of the School.
It is out of question to raise cattle for beef, for the timothy hay
which is growing well on our farm could easily be sold at $25.00
a ton. Consequently, by reducing the number of cows, I will also reduce
feed, labor and wages.

Now, we have a stock of old and degenerated
cows, which ought to be put away, and replaced by new ones of
pure breed.
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith a letter received from the Principal of the Fort Frances Indian School, in which he asks to be let sell six of their herd. And asks the Dept to purchase for them, a registered bull and cow, now I think this is a very foolish thing to ask the Dept, if they want to reduce their stock let them do so, but let them take the proceeds of the sale and replace with two registered animals.

I have the honor to be,

SIR.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

15 November 1929

To Mr. A. Spencer Ind. Agent

Dear Sir:

I come back again to ask you to solicit the Dept. of Indian Affairs to permit us to buy four or five head of Cattle for the school. Actually we have only on hand 4 milking cows, 1 bull and a calf. It is not sufficient for the need of the school. In my estimate we need about 8 good milking cows for the necessity of the children, and I see the school in the impossible to buy from its own fund.

I received a word from Rev. Father Guy who was in Ottawa lately and he encourages us to apply to the Dept. for the permit to buy some. Actually there are two (2) nice heifers to be sold at a fair price and they are expected to arrive soon... It is a good occasion.

To give an account of the stock from the beginning of the school, for me, it is an impossibility because I have been away different times. But I remember I bought myself the first two (2) milking Cows and the two horses we had. And when I left in 1909 I had four (4) head of Cattle and two (2) horses that have been bought when we built the school. I come back in 1916 I found that the stock was fourteen to sixteen head about I do not remember well, and when I left in 1925 I had 16 head from which flock we were killing for the use of the school. We had then the beef for most of the year. And this year, when I come back I found seven head of Cattle and among them two(2) were sick and we were obliged to kill them.

When I took charge of the school in February last I asked the oldest boys what happened to the cattle under the administration of Rev. Father Perreault? They said: We don't know, but we found one morning that three of them were dead.
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith a letter I received from Principal of the Fort Frances Residential School, in which he is requesting the Department to purchase for the School, four head of milk cows. No doubt but the children should have plenty of milk, but according to his statement, in the last five years their herd has dwindled from 16 head to six head of cattle, and no account of what has been done with them, I do not know what the custom of the Dept. is, in regard to furnishing stock for the Schools, so I will have to leave the question in your hands, either to grant or refuse the request.

I have the honor to be,

Sir.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

I have been requested by Mr. Smith to send you a copy of the report on the Wikwemikong School. The report contains detailed information about the school's operations, including enrollment numbers, funding sources, and educational programs.

The school currently has an enrollment of 150 students, with a staff of 20 teachers and administrators. The school offers a comprehensive curriculum, focusing on both academic and vocational training. The vocational training program includes courses in carpentry, auto mechanics, and electronics.

In addition to the Wikwemikong School, there is also an Orphanage located on the reserve. The Orphanage provides care and education for orphaned children. The Department of Education has made provisions for the Orphanage, ensuring that the children receive proper care and education.

The Department of Education has also made provisions for the Shingwauk Home, which provides care and education for children who are not orphaned. The Shingwauk Home has a staff of instructors to meet the requirements of the Department. The Department has made provision for an additional number of pupils at the Wikwemikong Institution.

I have the honor to inform you that your application for increased assistance having been fully considered, the Department regrets that it cannot increase the present grant of $300 nor entertain the proposition that the present grant of $300 be increased to the "Fort William Orphanage."

General History

The Fort William Orphanage was first established in 1870 by ladies from France devoted to charitable work.

The first object of the institution was the Education of the young Indian girls on the Fort William Reserve and neighbouring places.

During the first years only Indian girls were instructed in the Orphanage. They were taught English and the various household duties. Later, in addition to the Indian girls the Institution also received white children.

The Institution bore all the expenses in connection with the Educational support of the children at the Orphanage, most of its funds being received from a society in France. The first "Fort Grant" being made toward the support in 1883.

The building at that time (1883) consisted of a two storey frame, 40 x 50 feet with accommodation for about 130 pupils.

The first Government support asked for in connection with the Orphanage was when on the 15 Aug/82, the Directors forwarded a petition to the Governor General in which the above facts were set forth.
Grant (continued)

The O.C. dated June 22/76 or July 19/6588 of the September quarter 1875, when an order in Council was passed authorizing a grant of £500 annually to the Boys' School. They now receive a grant of £500 per annum from the Crown which amount is paid to the trustees of St Joseph.

The Debt did not contribute anything towards the support of Orphanage Boarding School till 1885 when it was said a yearly grant of £300 which amount it continued to receive each year up to and including the year 1889.

In 1890, the grant to the Orphanage was increased to £500 per annum which amount it has received from the Government each year since 1890.

The Orphanage is paid a straight yearly grant of £500 and not by a per capita allowance.

Situation:
The Fort William Orphanage Boarding School, or St. Joseph's Home as it is also known, is situated on the Kaministiquia River on the Fort William Indian Reserve near the town of Fort William Algoma, Ont.

There is one acre of land in connection with the school.

It is a Roman Catholic institution, the work of teaching being carried on under the auspices of the Sisters of St. Joseph.

The Home is a two-story frame building 70 x 45 feet, with basement and rests on a stone foundation. The School is an old frame building 44 x 20 feet.

The buildings are heated by two furnaces in which wood is burned. They are supplied with water from the river by means of a force pump.

The Fort William Orphanage Boarding School was first opened in the year 1870. There is also a Boys' and a Girls' Day School run in connection with the Orphanage. These two day schools were opened in 1868, but the Board did not contribute any grant till 1870.

Sir,

I desire to bring before you the financial condition of the Indian Boarding School conducted by the Sisters of St. Joseph at Fort William. The annual government grant is only $500, though the Sisters board, lodge and instruct between 30 to 35 Indian children. You will readily perceive that this sum is barely sufficient to properly clothe the pupils, leaving aside their maintenance and other expenses. Besides, the Sisters have to deprive themselves of many things that, if not strictly necessary, would tend to their comfort, and they leave undone much that they would desire to do, in order to suitably clothe and feed the children in our care. The house is thus most economical.

These Indian children come from the reserves of Lake Superior, and during the past year the Sisters maintained 38 Indian children, 15 boys and 23 girls, in the Fort William Boarding School. At present there are still cases for the admission of 7 or 8 more from the River and their reserves. This school has, during past years, received considerable help from the various sources. The Government grant is very meagre in the annual budget.
The Fort William school furnishes a comfortable home and good education for young children and although it is most economically managed, they had a deficit last year of over $200.00. The contributions from other sources than the Department amounted to $1309.85. This is a large amount to raise by voluntary contribution in that neighborhood and must have caused the management a good deal of labor and anxiety to secure.

I can see no reason why this school should not be recognized by the usual per capita grant of $60.00 for a limited number of pupils. The Indians along the North Shore of Lake Superior are of nomadic habits and most of them take their children with them on their hunts.

There seems no reason for enlarging the present building unless to provide accommodation for all the children on the reserve, day pupils as well as boarders. A new schoolhouse is required, so the Agent and School Inspector state, but the cost of the proposed building would make too great an inroad upon the funds of the Band, although the Indians are quite willing to contribute to this purpose. If a separate school building were put up, the present Orphanage has accommodation for more than the Department would probably be willing to make a grant for; as none but orphans from the Reserve should be taken.

Ottawa, November 6, 1910.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 31st ultimo in further reference to the admission of children to the Fort William Orphanage.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will, as Your Lordship was informed in official letter of May 4th, last, allow the admission of certain pupils outside the Thunder Bay District on the conditions as set forth in that letter.

The question of establishing a school at Matchewan Bay will receive consideration, but I may inform Your Lordship that it is a difficult matter to obtain teachers for schools along the shores of Lake Superior.

The Goulais Bay school is at present in need of a teacher and the Department would be glad to know of anyone qualified to take charge of this school. Perhaps Your Lordship could recommend a suitable person for this position.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Right Rev. D. J. Scollard, D.D., Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Bishop of Anuit Ote, Marie,
North Bay, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to discuss the department's plans to increase the Indian attendance at Fort William Residential School for the following reasons:

1. This school was originally intended to accommodate at least 200 Indian children. Yet, they have never been able to maintain this number due to very small enrollment.

2. There is a large territory for the school to draw from, namely places like Kenora Bay, Long Lake, Moosonee, Sioux Lookout, and the whole north shore of Lake Superior. This is why one school in each district would be more effective than the current setup at Fort William.

3. The present teachers are not fully qualified Indians, lacking proper experience.

4. The building is well adapted for a boarding school. It has a large outdoor area, plenty of playgrounds, fireplaces, balconies, and a admirable location. The outdoor facilities at Fort William make it a very suitable building.

5. Many of the Indian children now at the school are unable to communicate effectively in English. Many need assistance in this area.

Kindly do your best in this matter and I will be appreciated.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

J.M. Bennett
OTTAWA, June 11th, 1921.

Sir,

I beg to draw your attention to the present enrollment at St. Joseph's Orphanage, Fort William.

The last return received shows an enrollment of 19 pupils, while a per capita grant is provided for 35 pupils. It is understood that this school was built to accommodate 50 Indian children, but the enrollment has never been more than about 25. The Separate School Inspector, Mr. J. M. Bennett, draws the attention of the Department to the small attendance of Indian children, and requests that steps be taken to increase the attendance. There is a large territory for this school to draw from, viz: Horn Bay, Long Lake, River, Pays Plat and along the northern shore of Lake Superior.

The Inspector states that the building is well adapted for a boarding school; they have a good ventilation system; plenty of fresh air; fireplaces; balconies in a splendid situation on the outskirts of Fort William. I have, therefore, requested that this summer, when making visits to the various Reserves, you will endeavor to secure a number of pupils for this school. Care should be taken to see that they are Catholics or non-Catholics and in good health. In the event that any children be obtained, applications signed by one or other of the parents and a certificate of health signed by the Doctor should be forwarded on the usual form for that purpose.

The Missionaries could, no doubt, assist you in obtaining a number of new pupils.

The Department will expect that when this school resumes operations after the summer holidays, that there will be a good enrollment of new pupils, and you should use every endeavor you can with that end in view.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLennan,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.
OTTAWA, June 11th, 1931.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the attendance at St. Joseph's Orphanage, Fort William.

In reply, I beg to say that the Department is taking this matter up with its Agent, Mr. W. R. Brown, Port Arthur, and requesting him, when he visits the Reserves in his Agency during the present summer, to endeavour to secure a number of new pupils for this school.

There is provision made for a grant for 35 children, while the last return shows an enrollment of only 19.

The Agent has also been requested to consult the local Catholic Missionaries, under whose charge the various Reserves are situated, with a view to obtaining their assistance in inducing the Indian parents to allow their children to attend this school.

I have to thank you for drawing the attention of the Department to this matter, and it is hoped that as a result of the Agent's endeavours that a decided increase in the enrollment will take place.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLellan,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. M. Bennett, Esq., B.A.,
47 Bronson Ave.,
TORONTO, ONT.
I would suggest that this school be sent its full possible allowance of 35 Indian children. They can easily handle them as there are two classroom teachers and about 9 others for care of them outside the class work. At present there are 31.

This school is so situated that it should be accessible to more Indians than at present or at least its quota of 35 being kept filled.
OTTAWA, April 1st, 1922.

Sir,

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Fort William Orphanage recommends that this school be recruited up to the full number of pupils for which the grant is allowed, vizt 35. He states that at the time of his visit there were 31 Indian children enrolled, and recommends that the full quota of 35 be regularly in attendance.

I have, therefore, to request that you will endeavour, with the assistance of the school authorities, to recruit a sufficient number of children to keep the average attendance up to the number of grant earning pupils allowed. Care should be taken to see that the children admitted are Native Canadians of school age and in good health. An application signed by one or other of the parents and the certificate of health signed by the doctor should be forwarded for each child obtained.

As there is a large territory for this school to draw from there should be no difficulty in keeping this school filled to capacity.

You will be good enough to give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
This school is under able management. The number of Indians arranged to attend this school is 35. I feel however that since there are only two day schools from Charlevoix to Kenora and Fort Frances, this boarding school could easily be allowed to increase their quota. From Heron Bay, Payette Flat, Missinabie, Jackfish, Long Lake, etc., could be brought many Indian children who are now going to illiterate. I feel that certain schools are the more satisfactory.
Ottawa, April 23rd, 1923.

Madam:

The Separate School Inspector, who recently visited the Fort William Orphanage, suggests that this Department allow for an increase in the pupilage in order to provide for a number of Indian children from Heron Bay, Pays Plat, Missinabie, Jackfish, Long Lac, etc., who are not now attending any school and are growing up without an education.

I shall be pleased if you will state the number of Indian children for whom you can provide accommodation. At the present time you are aware, I am allowed for 35 children, and if you could take a larger number so would be prepared to favourably consider providing a grant for the full number which your school can accommodate, in order that the children from the Reserves mentioned above can have an opportunity of receiving an education.

I shall be pleased if, at your earliest convenience, you will inform us fully as to what accommodation you can provide, stating the full number of Indian children you would be willing to receive without, in any way, overcrowding the dormitories or classrooms.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Sister M. J. O'Connell,

Ottawa, May 4th, 1923.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, stating the number of children for which accommodation can be provided in the Fort William Orphanage.

In reply I beg to say that it is hoped to be able to arrange for a representative of the Department to visit Fort William during the coming summer regarding the question of making provision for the full number of children whom you can accommodate.

In the meantime, you may accept any orphan or substitute children from the reserves at Heron Bay, Pays Plat, Blackknife, Jackfish, Long Lac and from those Indian families residing along the line of railway. We shall allow a supernumerary grant for any orphan or substitute child taken into the school in excess of the number of vacant places now being provided for. Pro or applications and certifications of health for admission should be forwarded to the office of your local Indian Agent.

As the funds at our disposal this year have been assigned to the various purposes for which they were provided, it will not be possible to arrange for a rent for 50 pupils, the number which you state you can accommodate, but, if satisfactory arrangements are made, this number of children can be provided for in our estimates for the next fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sister M. F. Clare,
St. Joseph's Orphanage,
Fort William, Ont.

Sir:

I enclose herewith copy of a communication received from Mrs. Catherine Wabas, of the Pigeon River Band, regarding the death of her son, John Wabas, pupil of the Fort William Orphanage. Please enquire into this case and report. You should state why the boy was allowed to leave the school when he was in a serious condition of health.

Unless in cases of urgent necessity the Principal should not allow Indian children to leave the school without first obtaining the permission of the Department. She should make application through your office to the Department setting forth clearly the reason for requesting the discharge of, or for allowing, pupil back to home. It is considered that there should be very few instances in which it would be necessary for the Principal to allow a pupil to leave the school before obtaining the authority of the Department.

Your early reply regarding the complaint of Catherine Wabas as to the treatment and death of her son will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

August 18th, 1924.

Mr. J. G. Burke,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of August 15th, regarding the death of John Wabase, I wish to say that in the earlier part of June he caught "German Measles", and in the absence of Doctor Gillie, we called in Doctor Arnaud, who pronounced that the children had a slight attack of "German Measles", and that the treatment was, to keep them in bed and warm for four or five days, which was done. As John did not seem to get strong, we again sent him to Doctor Gillie, who gave him a prescription for a tonic, but gave no order to send the boy to the Hospital, and as the Sisters in charge of the boys say that the boy before he went ill, and Doctor who was treating him, said the boy had a very weak chest. When he went out home for the holidays, however, he gained up and returned to school in September feeling very much improved in health, and we naturally thought the same would be the case this year. I did not send the boy home, he only left the School for the holidays as per the usual custom.

As regards Mrs. Wabase's complaint about the scrubbing of the floor in Class-room, it would be an order from the Teacher, and there would likely be four or five other boys helping him. We also wish to say that Mr. Burke has been very kind and attentive to his duties with the School during the past year.

We regret that the poor boy died so soon after going home, and I know his mother will miss him, and also get a shock at his sudden death.

Trusting the above explanation will be satisfactory,
I remain,

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

Veronica.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I would be very grateful if you would advise me if the Indian children at St. Joseph's Boarding School at Fort William, are clothed by the Department, or if the Indian parents are expected to provide their children's clothes.

I have a girl at the above mentioned school on whom I am obliged to spend a lot of money buying her clothes. I also have to pay for having her shoes repaired.

It is really as expensive to me to have her there as to keep her here myself, as she seems to wear her clothes out faster there than here at home.

Please answer me if it does not take too much trouble, and thanking you in advance for same, I am,

Yours respectfully,

Peter Panitomines.

October 27th 1930

REPORT

Patrol to Savanne I.R.—Assistance to Dept; of Indian Affairs.

First Report:

Acting on instructions received from the H.C.O. I/a Fort William, Ont; Detachment, I left Fort William at 7.30am of the 25th inst; and patrolled by C.Ply to Savanne I.R., arriving at Savanne at 8.27am, O.T. of the same date.

This patrol was in connection with a request from the Indian Agent, Mr. J.G.Burk, to ascertain if an Indian boy, Joseph Pism, was resident on the reserve, and if so to bring him to Fort William Indian School, where he should be attending, and also to investigate the condition among the Indians at the reserve.

On arrival at Savanne, however, I found that the lake was frozen over to the extent of 2 inches in depth, and all navigation stopped. As the only way of reaching the reserve is by water, there being no overland trail, and the ice not yet being safe, I wired Sergt. Mann, Y.F. for instructions, and he wired that I return by the next train. This I did arriving in Fort William in the pm of the same date.

Brims, April 26th, 1931.

Sir,

The Department has been providing grant for seventy-five (75) pupils at the Fort William Indian Residential School. It is noted that there are now ninety-three (93) children on the roll and the March quarter return shows an average attendance of eighty-eight (88). It has been decided to provide grant for eighty-five (85) pupils and, also, allow supernumerary grant for three (3) pupils for the March and June quarters. After the end of June it will still be possible to allow grant for eighty-five (85) pupils at this school. You should inform the Reverend Sister Superior and, if there are any children who could be discharged at the end of June, application should be made to the Department. In the event of any being sent home at that time, it would permit of accommodation being available for any deserving cases, within the number for which grant is provided.

EXTRACT from Inspector Greening's Report on his visit to the FORT WILLIAM INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on June 17, 1932.

Original on File 9-11-6.

The high state of efficiency previously reported has been maintained at this school.

There has just been held at Fort William a convention of the Urban School Trustees of Ontario, the convention being also attended by the Chief Director and the Chief Inspector of Public and Separate Schools, of the Provincial Department of Education. The latter spent quite a time at the school, seeing it at work (so that he might see just what was being done) I made sure that the school authorities did NOT know that they were to be visited) and was, I believe, very much impressed with the efficiency shown.

In addition to the activities mentioned in previous reports, I might mention that Mother St. George has arranged to have an ex-military man give the children instruction in Physical Training. This year he has given all the senior children (from Grade VII up) a thorough course in First Aid. When examined by an outside authority for their First Aid Certificates these children made an average mark of well over 90 per cent.

Fort William Residential School offers a much more many-sided instruction than any other Indian School visited by me and well deserves the greatest possible praise and consideration.
Sir:

With reference to the enclosed Quarterly School report received from the St. Joseph's Boarding School, as you will note there are 108 pupils attending the School. This is 23 over the required quota.

Owing to the fact of so much destitution this year the Mother Superior advised that rather than turn the children away they would, if necessary, take them free of charge. I informed the Rev. Mother that I would communicate with our Department to ascertain if a further grant could be made to remunerate the Boarding School.

I may say that there are several cases reported to me by the Missionary, Rev. J. Couture as being unable to provide food for the children. If these children are sent to the Boarding School they are properly clothed, and fed. Unfortunately the blueberry crop upon which the Indians depend to purchase supplies for the fall harvest was total failure, as far as the Indians were concerned. This fact has caused a great deal of destitution.

Your obedient servant,

J. O. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, October 25th, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your 210-84 of the 17th instant, with reference to the September quarter return of the Fort William Indian Residential School.

It is noted that the number of Indian children at present in residence is 168, while per capita allowance is only authorized for 15. Were these children placed in this school at your request? It is possible to take from the second paragraph of your letter the meaning that the Sister Superior admitted them without consulting you.

The Department realizes that, owing to present conditions, there is a great demand for institutional care but, before considering per capita allowance for the extra number of pupils, the Department desires to be assured that the parents are not simply imposing on the good nature of the Sister Superior.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. G. Bark, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.
Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 26th ult., file No. 9-11-1, with reference to the number of Indian children enrolled at the St. Joseph's Boarding School, I wish to state that these children were brought to the Boarding School from various points where no schooling is available, during my absence in September. During the summer months the missionary and myself interviewed the parents of these children who were living in destitute and unsanitary conditions, with a view to their sending them to the Boarding School.

On my return to the office the Sister Superior communicated with me advising that 23 children over the quota allowed had been brought to the School. The Sister requested that I inform the Department of the existing circumstances, stating that they would keep these children free of charge rather than turn them away, but would very much appreciate if some further grant could be allowed.

In conclusion I may say the Boarding School is doing excellent work, and is very highly recommended by Mr. Greening, the School Inspector. I would recommend that the Boarding School be recompensed for the extra children above the quota.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Dr. McGill,

The following is contained in a letter addressed to the Minister:

"I have received a letter from a very prominent citizen at the Head of the Lams in which he says that the allowance to St. Joseph's Orphanage for the care of certain Indian Children has been reduced. This institution is having great difficulty in making things go and while I understand the reduction is only fifteen per cent, it means a great deal to them. I should appreciate it very much if you could favourable consider letting the former grant stand."

Will you please furnish the Minister with a report on this matter.

George Buskard

December 23, 1934.

Memo:

MR. BUSKARD,

I have your memorandum of the 8th instant, regarding the communication addressed to the Honourable the Minister, from a prominent citizen at the Head of the Lakes, requesting that the reduction made in the grant to the St. Joseph's Orphanage, Port William, be restored.

In this connection I have to say that per capita grants to all Indian residential schools were reduced 10% as from January 1, 1933, and there was a further reduction of 5% from January 1, 1934 - making a total reduction in grants of 15%.

I may say that this institution is privately owned. The Department provides grant for 60 Indian children at the rate of $150 per capita, less 10%. The enrollment of Indian children has fallen off during the current academic year. This will account for a decrease in the amount paid, which is affecting, to some extent, the finances of the institution. Besides the Indian children, the Department understands there are a number of white orphan children in the institution.

Regarding the request that the grant be restored, I have to say that this school should receive the same consideration as other Indian residential schools, which are all subject to the reduction of grant, as mentioned above.

From the Fort William Daily Journal
Wednesday, 10th April, 1895

DISASTEROUS FIRE
Fort William Reserve

St. Joseph's Convent, Orphanage, and Catholic Church Destroyed

St. Joseph's Convent and Orphanage and Catholic church took fire about half past nine last night morning.

The fire originated in a bake oven in the back part of the orphanage. All the Indians were at prayers at the time which was very fortunate, as the fire spread so rapidly that the firemen were unable to save anything.

An alarm was sounded at a quarter to seven from Town Hall, to which our Fire Brigade responded promptly. They were unable to save the Convent, and were driven from the Church by the intense heat. All that is left is the interior of the private house and the outbuildings, which they were able to save, although two firemen were badly burned.

It is stated that the Indians say "the Fort William people were quick to come, and managed to save the private house and outbuildings, for which they are much thanked."

The Convent and Orphanage was saved. All the children were gotten safely out of the building, which was saved from the fire by the efforts of Mr. Donnelly who has replaced the school board. The children have been sent to relatives and friends until such time as the Indians may be given a temporary orphanage. The school board has offered their school as a temporary orphanage for the children until such time as the Indians may be given a permanent orphanage.

If the fire had occurred in the night or in severely cold weather the suffering would have been far greater. There is real cause for thankfulness that the fire occurred at this time when the Indians were up and about and the weather was fine.

The Convent was built in the district being nearly fifty years old. The main part of the convent was erected about twenty-five years ago. The convent was insured for $6000 and the church for $2000. The orphanage is a building which the Sisters of St. Joseph purchased several years ago. The orphanage was used as a school when opened, but at the time they were closed everything was empty except the school buildings. It is hoped that something will be done to assist the Indians.
Port Arthur 10th April 1895

Sir,

I have to report to your Department that the Fort William Reserve St. Joseph's Convent and Orphanage burnt this morning at 6:30 o'clock A.M. The Roman Catholic Church also, the Sisters were up and dressed, but the children were not, and many of them close and shoes lost. The long school house about one hundred feet away from the orphanage was saved, and is occupied for the present by the Reverend Mother Superior and the Sisters, and the Indians gave them their Council House for school and other purposes, until some other arrangement is made. I expended about three dollars on the Council House by a new lock and some other repair necessary, and bought 47½ lbs of material at a cost of about $10.50 to both the orphan, and about $4.50 to replace shoes, there was also a good deal given and assistance rendered by the Fort William people. This I took upon myself to do for the Department and used very economy and worked hard all day assisting.

I forward also an account of the sale of the Fort William today.

I am Sir,

Deputy Superintendent

Rev. J. H. Daly, M.P.,
Minister of the Interior

Dear Sir,

I desire to introduce to you Rev. Dr. Casey,
Archdeacon of the Diocese of Peterborough. He will
therefore before you some matters of great importance to the
Indians of Fort William. On the morning of 18th inst., the
church and orphanage of that place were entirely destroyed
by fire. Fortunately all the orphans, numbering over
fifty, were rescued in safety by the Indians in charge.
The orphanage was valued at about two thousand
dollars, but there was an insurance of five thousand
dollars so that the church was insured for only one
thousand dollars. You understand that it will be
necessary to rebuild both church and orphanage as soon as
possible, so as to provide for the necessities of the orphan
and the religious requirements of the Indians. On this
account I most earnestly appeal to the Government for
sufficient aid to enable the Indians to continue the
good work they have been performing in educating
and supporting the orphaned children to help the Indians to
rebuild the church.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

OTTAWA 26th April, 1895

Hon. T. Mayne Daly,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs

Respecting the letter under from Bishop O'Connor appealing for aid towards the re-building of the Church and Orphanage which were destroyed by fire at Fort William, the undersigned would report that the Deputy Minister of Justice has already expressed the opinion that under Section 70 of the Indian Act, the Governor-in-Council can, without the consent of the Band, make contributions from Indian capital towards the repair, enlargement or reconstruction of a school-house in which a school is to be held attended by Indians. The Fort William Band have at their credit capital amounting to $14,354.77. The undersigned believes that no better use could be made of the moneys at the credit of Indians than expending them in the erection and maintenance of schools, and he would be prepared to recommend that a contribution of $1,000 should be made from the Fort William funds for the erection of a building to replace the Orphanage.

Under the law we cannot contribute anything from the Indian funds towards the reconstruction of the Church, but, of course, if the Council
reason) with a recommendation that the extra sum be granted.

As to the restoration of the Church (and in such a contribution could be made for the purpose) I have through a Resolution of the Band, received the Excellency's Council. . . .

Your Lordship,

T. Macdonald
Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

His Lordship,

Rev. R.A. O'Connor
Bishop of Peterborough

Peterborough, Ont.
I am obliged to inform Your Lordship that I have been requested by Mr. Smith, the Superintendent of the Indian Department, to make an inquiry into the state of the Indians in the district of Fort William. He has informed me that there are about 150 Indians living in the district, and that they are in a very poor condition. They are suffering from various diseases, and many of them are unable to work.

Mr. Smith has also informed me that the Indians are in great need of assistance, and that they would be grateful for any help that could be given to them. He has asked me to recommend to Your Excellency in Council that a contribution of £1,000 be made from the capital of the Fort William fund to help in reconstructing the Orphanage. However, the Indians desire a larger amount of their money should be expended, and they pass a Resolution to that effect. I should be happy to submit the Resolution to Council (always provided, of course, that the amount to be contributed be within reason).

Sir,

I have acknowledged the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, and with reference to the item of $50 forwarded for expenditure incurred on the purchase of seed potatoes for the Orphanage, I desire to explain why you purchased them at 50¢ per bushel instead of the cheaper variety which would have answered quite as well. The price is considered too high by the Department and I shall make further explanations. In regard to the item in question, I have been instructed to purchase seed potatoes for the body of the Indian orphanage. It will be necessary for you to furnish me with an estimate of the amount required on this account.

I have noted what was said in the Resolution of Council, which you forwarded as to the loss by the Indians of their seed potatoes, and you may purchase 50 bushels at 50¢ per bushel to replace these. The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that on the 20th April last, the Indian Orphanage at Fort William was destroyed by fire. The building was valued at about $10,000, and was insured for $5,000. OTTAWA, 25th June, 1900.

The Secretary:

Mr Agent Hodder encloses a communication from the Sisters of St Joseph asking for a grant to assist them in paying for the building of a fence around the yard at the Fort William Orphanage and also for the cost of a hen house, amounting in all to $130.00. There are 28 children on the roll at this school, which receives a grant of $500 per annum from the Government. The buildings are new and convenient and cost nearly $7000.00, one thousand of which was contributed by the Fort William Band. These Indians get the benefit of this school and pay very little for it, and if their funds would stand a contribution I think they might be asked to assist in paying for this outlay.

Some time ago the Sisters asked for an increased grant, which was not allowed, and it must be drawing pretty heavily on the resources of their Church of their finances to keep up such an institution upon a grant of only $500.00.

[Signature]

Martin Borden
Memorandum:

For the Secretary,

The only suggestion that I can make in regard to assisting the management of the Ft. William Orphanage in meeting the expense of the hen-house and fence, is to pay half the amount from the "Miscellaneous" item in the appropriation for schools in Ontario and Quebec.

This vote will bear the charge; the interest account of the Ft. William Band will not; and I do not take it to be a fair charge against that account, solely as pupils attend the Institution who belong to other Bands in Agent Hodder's district.

I should certainly like to see some assistance given as the school is excellently managed; and its current cost to the Department is very small compared to the value of the work it performs.

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of March 24th last, with regard to the payment of $1000 towards the building of an addition to the St. Joseph's Orphanage on the Fort William reserve, and your reply thereto, dated March 30, (file No. 158616-1), I beg to repeat the opinion which I expressed in that letter; viz.: that all such grants towards the erection or repairs of buildings which are not erected or repaired under the direct control of some Department of the Government, should be specifically voted by Parliament.

In your reply above referred to you state that this amount was included in the item for schools in the supplementary estimates of your Department, voted by Parliament; that is, I take it, in the supplementary sum of $3800 voted for schools during the session of 1903. It may be that the $1000 in question was one of the payments anticipated by you when you made up this estimate, but as the particular items making up this amount of $3800 were not submitted to Parliament, Parliament cannot be said to have specifically voted this grant. So far as the authorisation of Parliament went the expenditure of the amount thus voted was not limited in any way other than it was to be expended on Indian Schools. Kindly in future have all such grants specifically voted.

General-

The building, as designed, is on the whole excellent, is thoroughly equipped and maintained in a good and satisfactory manner. The school authorities appear thoroughly efficient and earnestly enthusiastic in their work; and are entitled to every commendation; excepting for a few minor details in the arrangement of the building, particularly the lack of sufficient window space in boys' latrine, ventilation in dormitories and contracted class-room space. With regard to the lighting of latrine, I understood the Mother Superior to say that it was their purpose to provide additional light as soon as weather would admit of doing the work also that ventilation would be provided as soon as sketch of Department's requirements was sent to them.

The principal class-room, while having a floor space to accommodate 56 pupils has air space for 24 only, this might be sufficient for their present needs as this school, like others of its class, giving manual as well as scholastic training, a portion of the pupils taking the classes while the others are engaged in the practical work. Notwithstanding this, I am of the opinion that a well proportioned class-room separate from the building, properly lighted and ventilated is in the interest of the school and, I believe, that on the request of the Department, as soon as financial conditions are favourable, better class-room facilities will be provided.

The drains, plumbing and plumbing fixtures throughout the building were sanitary and in good condition at the time of my inspection.

Right Reverend Sir,

Mr. Separate School Inspector O'Brien has again drawn the attention of the Department to the fact that the class-room space at the Fort William Orphanage is inadequate and that the room is very badly ventilated.

Your Lordship will recollect that the Department has had previous correspondence with you in regard to this matter and in the last communication received, dated January 12th, last, Your Lordship stated that it was the intention to provide more class-room accommodation, but the decision had not been reached as to means that would be adopted. As the continuance of the grant to this school is dependent upon the terms of the contract being carried out, I shall be pleased to know from Your Lordship when it is proposed to go ahead with this work.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Later on, at the time when the Indian children cannot come to school, she gets as salary only $300 per annum. She comes all the way from Montreal. Bearing in mind the cost of living in this part of Ontario, and especially at Nepigon where there is no competitive transportation, this teacher can save little or nothing on $300. She should have 30 to 40 Indian children in the school, and if the accommodation were better and the teacher paid better more pupils would be found at school.

I would impress on the Department the necessity of getting school buildings here, new desks and better equipment, also better quarters for the teacher, and a salary of at least $400 per annum for the teacher. We will get our school buildings in first class order but the Department while urging us to hang up with improvements should hurry itself up to make improvements on the school buildings which it owns. "Medicus cura te ipsum."

Yours very sincerely,

I think taking everything into consideration this Fort William Building must be one of the best in the Country, and I venture to remark, that when our contemplated improvements are completed it will be second to none in the Country.

I am making a tour this year of all the Indian villages on the north shore of Lake Superior, and I must aver that the school buildings in many of these places are very poor, and the equipment of such schools wretched. The school at Jackfish Island on Lake Nipigon well - it is the limit. The school at Helen Leake near this village of Nipigon is in a miserable state, nothing cheerful or inviting about it. The building is old, the foundation is giving away under it. The class-room is hard to keep warm. The teachers quarters are very poor, and the teachers and pupils desks are horrid. Sir,

A large addition to the Fort William Boarding School for Indians and their children is in course of construction. A fire escape consisting of an iron pipe was placed on the side of the new building. From the second floor of the new building, the escape could be used by those who needed it. The escape was constructed so that it would not interfere with the operation of the school.

The teachers and religious sisters in charge of the school were very pleased with the new addition. They found it very useful for the safety of the students. The school is equipped with the same kind of fire escape, and the teachers are pleased with them.

Another one of the same kind of fire escape was recently installed at the new addition, but the building inspectors of Fort William will not agree to anything but iron stairs for fire escapes on this Fort William building.
