No. 1 Laundry Equipment shall consist of one Washer and one Extractor, both operated by one motor mounted by bracket on Washer.

Power Transmission
The Power Transmission from the motor to the Washer and Extractor shall be supported by brackets bolted to tub frames of Washer, thereby making same self-contained. Pulleys shall be iron and belting first grade oak tanned.

Electrical Equipment
Shall be furnished for the following power characteristics:

(a) Direct Current

Motor

Alternating Current — Shall consist of enclosed switch with fuses.

Wiring

Reverend Mother Superior,

Mr. Cave has just returned from Fort William and he has taken up with us regarding an Extractor for your Laundry Department.

We are very fortunate at this time in having an Extractor which we have recently taken out of the Gravelbourg College, Gravelbourg, Sask. This machine was taken out on account of its size, and had not been used any more than two or three months.

This is a 20" Extractor, similar to the one enclosed and marked. As regards driving this Extractor, we have taken this matter up with our Engineering Department and the motor which you now have on your Washer is not sufficiently large enough to drive the Extractor as well as the Washer. Therefore, it would necessitate your getting a new motor and you could get one large enough about a 3 H.P., which would drive both the Extractor and Washer by having a belt from the motor up to the ceiling to the line shaft, then down to the Washer and Extractor.

The Extractor and motor would cost you $450.00 F.O.B. Winnipeg, and there also would be some Belting, Hangers, and shafting which you would have to purchase in Fort William for this job. However, it would give you a very nice lay-out in your laundry, and one which would be permanent for some time.

If you wish, we could send our Mr. Garrett down to look after this installation for you, providing you will pay his Railway fare and expenses while he is in Fort William.

Might state that we are putting these Extractors in most of the Indian Schools and other Institutions, and besides being fool-proof, they look after the wringing in such a better manner than the old type Rubber Wringer.

Dear Sir:

I have two Indian youngsters named Deschamps and Michelson at St. Joseph's Orphanage, suffering from pneumonia following whooping cough.

These youngsters were very ill, and as they could not get the required attention and care in the Boarding School, I interviewed Mother Superior of St. Joseph's Hospital, and asked her if she would take them. As they had to be isolated she said she would do so providing the Department would pay for special nurses as she didn't have any nurses she could spare to look after these cases. I took it upon myself after consulting with you to put on a day and night nurse. I think this was good judgment as these two youngsters are making rapid progress towards recovery and will be able to leave the Institution in a few days.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) J. C. Gillie.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, the Department did not authorize any expenditure at the Fort William Residential School in official letter of October 13, 1945. We simply asked you to let us know if there was anything needed. In fact, we received a request for books and other classroom material. Dear Sir:

Your letter dated May 27th, duly received, and regret my seemingly neglect in answering it till this late date.

Fortunately His Excellency, the most Reverend R.H. Dignan was in Fort William early in June, and we discussed both your letters.

The most necessary improvements requiring immediate attention, are on the building. For instance the exterior woodwork has not been painted for twenty-three years.

I am enclosing an estimate from Mr. John Heilman who, in the past, has done very satisfactory work for us. Mr. Heilman has painting contracts with local schools which are not just ready yet, so he could undertake our painting job immediately, if we had the Department's permission to proceed with the work.

Should this not meet with the approval of the Department- we will submit other necessary improvements to our building such as, repairs to fire escapes,- quotations received for same $297.00, new roof, cost estimated at $3,280.00 and at least three porches for school and play-room entrances.

An immediate reply will be greatly appreciated.

Dear Mr. Burk,

At the time of Mr. Neary's visit here he explained to us the manner in which we were to benefit by the proposed special Grant which is being allotted to our Schools this year. He suggested that we send in our requisitions at an early date, for equipment and maintenance, covering the amount of our allotment.

We have been informed that our water pipes should be replaced by copper piping. Therefore, we had our local plumber prepare an estimate of the approximate amount of material required for this work, copy of which is enclosed.

We find that the drying facilities in our laundry are inadequate, so deem it advisable to procure a Tumbler to take care of this work. Our present laundry equipment was procured from the J.H. Connor & Son Ltd., Ottawa. Knowing that St. Joseph's Manor is using one of these Tumblers we contacted them with a view to purchasing its capacity, etc. A few days later when the Company's representative called there they referred him to us. We informed him that while we were interested, we were not in a position to place the order. This was being taken care of by the Federal Government.

It would facilitate the preparing of our Reports if we had a wide carriage typewriter. We are therefore requesting one of these - an eighteen inch carriage.

Our caretaker has requested fifty yards of half-inch garden hose. This too has been entered on our list.

Thanking you in anticipation of your kind attention to the enclosed.

Yours very truly,

Fort William Indian Residential School

Sister M. Thomasina,

File References Re: Frank FINLAYSON - Treaty Indian - Runaway Boy from St. Joseph's Orphanage, Fort William

5-6-39

1. Reference above, I have to report, at approximately 8 A.M., this date, a telephone message was received this morning from the Sister Superior, St. Joseph's Orphanage, Fort William, to the effect that Frank FINLAYSON, a treaty Indian boy had run away from the Orphanage.

2. A patrol was immediately made to St. Joseph's Orphanage and the Sister Superior interviewed, who stated that Frank FINLAYSON, an orphan boy, had run away from the Orphanage on the afternoon of the 3-6-39 and was accompanied by Percy FOWLER, a white boy, both boys being fourteen years of age. Description of these boys were obtained.

3. The Sister Superior further stated that she had received a telephone message from an aunt of the RUNAWAY boy giving the information that while she was visiting friends in Poole Township, both these boys had been seen in the vicinity of a farm owned by the grandfather of FOWLER, now deceased.

4. Acting on this information, accompanied by Sergeant, a patrol was made to the RUNAWAY farm at Poole Township. It was found upon arrival there that this farm had not been used for quite some time, probably since the death of Mr. FOWLER's Grandfather, a fire was smouldering in the shack on this property, and upon making enquiries of a neighboring farmer, information was received that the two boys had been in the shack during the morning and that they had headed up the road about an hour previous. Further that these boys were in possession of a bicycle, one riding said vehicle while the other rode on the cross bar.

5. Making enquiries of the farmers along the road it was learned that the boys had taken to the bush, fearing that these boys might get lost or be pursued through the bush was immediately taken and after an all day search through the bush, around the main lakes and farms of the district, the escapees were sighted crossing a field, they were presently overhauled and taken into custody.

6. The boys were questioned regarding the bicycle they had been seen with and RUNAWAY stated that he had taken the bicycle from a residence at Vickers Heights, just outside of the city of Fort William and further that the bicycle was hidden in the bush in the township of Poole.

7. The boys were returned to St. Joseph's Orphanage and Mr. JURKIN, Indian Agent, Port Arthur Notified of the return of FINLAYSON.

As you are aware, when Indian children reside close to a day school and the parents are able to support them it is the Department's policy not to remove them from the day school rather than a residential school. These children should not be sent to Fort William until we have officially approved of their admission and this permission cannot be granted until you report fully regarding your reasons for wishing them placed in a residential school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Attention-Chief Training Division

Sir:

I beg to enclose application for admission to the Fort William residential school for the following children:

Bertha Goodchild No.118 Pic
Lena Twance No. 110

With regard to these applications, I beg to report that while there is a day school at the Pic reservation, I would recommend that admission be granted to these two girls. In the home of Bertha Goodchild there are three other small children in poor health and the father has requested the admission of Bertha on the grounds that his wife be relieved of the responsibility of looking after her, as well as having her isolated from other members of the family, one of whom, has tuberculosis.

There are seven other children in the family of Lena Twance, and the reason for her request for admission to the school is practically the same as for Bertha Goodchild. Under the circumstances I would be pleased if the Department would grant admission to the two above mentioned girls.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

Attention-Chief, Training Division

Sir:

In reply to your letter of September 26th, file No. 9-11-10, with regard to applications for the admission of Lester and Mary Bouchard to the Fort William residential school, at Fort William, I beg to report that as the mother of these children is tubercular and in poor health, their admission was requested on the recommendation of Dr. Leveille of Nipigon, in order that the mother would be relieved of their cares and also to minimize the chance of the children contracting the disease. There are two other children to care for, and under the circumstances I would recommend that the applications for Lester and Mary be accepted.

I might add, that their admission has not yet been granted, but has been held over for your authorization.

Your obedient servant,

Port Arthur, Ont.,
March 7, 1941,

Attention-Chief, Training Div.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith, application for admission forms for 18 Indian children to the Fort William residential school, as well as the quarterly return for the period ending Dec. 31st, 1941, and admission and discharge forms.

You will note that there are several children enrolled from the Pic reserve. For your information, I wish to advise that the Doctor considered it advisable to send these children to the boarding school as they have tuberculosis in their families and in this way they were isolated from the rest of the family. In the summer holidays these children will camp out in tents and consequently will not be affected by direct contact with tubercular members of their families, as if they were living in their own homes.

Your obedient servant,

This woman was commuted from Robinson Treaty on August 19th, dept.'s file 25-3 and at that time commutation was refused her children until they reached the age of 21. I would be pleased if the Department would advise if authorization can be granted to admit these children to the school.

Your obedient servant,

J. O. Burk, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, September 8, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of August 25, the Department is prepared to approve the admission of the two children of Mrs. Doris Danielson, of MacDiarmid, Ont., to the Fort William Residential School. The usual application form and certificate of health should be submitted for our consideration.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Attention-Supt. of Welfare & Training

Dear Sir:

There are still a few Indian children, pupils of the Fort William residential school, who have not yet returned to commence the Fall term. On checking with their parents I find that they have not sufficient funds to pay the cost of transportation back to the school. I would be pleased therefore if you would authorize me to pay transportation costs of these pupils. It is difficult to estimate the cost accurately, until each case is investigated thoroughly, but every effort will be made to keep the cost as low as possible.

In the event funds are available for this purpose would you please advise if payment can be made by transportation warrant.

Yours truly,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

November 2nd, 1942

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir:

About two weeks ago I sent application forms for the admission of two children of Sampson Jackpine to the Fort William School.

Since that time Sampson Jackpine has died, and his widow is anxious to know whether the children will be going or not, as she wants to get in to the bush to trap.

The reason for them wanting to go to Fort William, instead of Spanish, which is nearer, is so that the Mother can visit them once a year or so, to Fort William it is a direct run, whereas to Spanish she would have to stay over in Sudbury a night going and returning.

Please advise if you have any decision made in their case.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

The name of Roy Echum, No. 281, was shown on the September quarter return of the Fort William Residential School but does not appear on the December quarter return, although no application has been received for his discharge. Please advise regarding this boy. You may inform the Principal that the admission of the following children is approved:

On the December quarter return there are the names of 50 pupils for whom no grant is requested. I presume that in the majority of cases these pupils were allowed home on holidays last June and have not yet returned. Carrying names on the return makes a lot of extra checking and, unless there are some reasonable prospects of these pupils returning to the school in the near future, I feel it would be advisable to apply for their discharge and this will permit their names being removed from the return. Ottawa,
May 25, 1943.

Mr. J.C. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, Ont.

In a report from the R.O.M.P. regarding a recent patrol to the reserve near Ignace, Ont., reference is made to an Indian boy named Jack Primeau, 6 years of age. He is stated to be living with Jack Boucher at Ignace who is reported to be mean to the boy and does not allow him to go to school. It is further stated that Jack Primeau was formerly a pupil of the Fort William Residential School. If the facts are as stated, the Department feels that arrangements should be made to return him to the Fort William Residential School. As soon as you have definite information regarding this boy you should advise this office.

Philip Phelan,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

We have your letter of the 28th, re Jack Primeau.

Our records show a Jack Primeau and his younger brother were sent here from Crilly, Ontario, September 27th, 1938. They were non-treaty. They remained here one year and did not return the following year. They returned in 1940 and at the end of the year their mother took them out and we have not seen them since that time.

Trusting this information may assist you,

we are,

Sincerely Yours,

Principal, Indian Residential School.
Fort Arthur, Ont.,
Sept. 2, 1943.

I am in receipt of a number of requests from widows of various bands in the agency for transportation for their children to enable them to return to the St. Joseph's Boarding School at Fort William. It has been pointed out to the Indians that it is their responsibility to see that the children are returned to the school at their own expense but there are a number of cases, particularly amongst widowed members who are not in a position to bear the cost. In many cases the Indians are members of bands that have band funds and the cost could be charged, where necessary, to same.

Every effort will be made to keep the cost of the above mentioned, to a minimum.

Would you kindly advise if it will be in order to accept accounts for transportation in this connection.

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Br., Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have a request today from Mrs. Kathleen Absikum, 89 Red Rock band, to admit her grandson Alan Hardy, age 11 years, to the Fort William residential school. This boy is the son of Kathleen [Absikum] Donic and the late Arthur Donic, who was killed on the K. K. Kangoo accidently in 1939. The mother married again and is now Mrs. John Hardy, No. 165 Red Rock band. Actually, the boy is not a Treaty Indian, but has been raised similar to other Treaty Indians of the agency, and under existing circumstances I would like authority to place him in the residential school, under the jurisdiction of our Department. Would you kindly advise if authority can be given to admit the above mentioned to the School.

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
December 12, 1944.

Mr. J.O. Burk, Indian Agent, Fort Arthur, Ont.

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to Alan Hardy. I infer from your letter that this boy's father was white and, if this inference is correct, he would not be eligible for admission as a grant-earning pupil to an Indian residential school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Port Arthur, Ont.,
Dec. 16th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Br., Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Alan Hardy

With further reference to my letter of the 8th instant and your reply of the 12th file No. 9-11-10 in the status of the named half-breed Indian boy, I have to advise that the Grandfather was a French half-breed. Both, Alan's mother and Arthur Dombo's (Alan's father) mother were full blood Indians.

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
December 27, 1944.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, Ont.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 16th instant, the Department does not consider Alan Hardy eligible for admission as a grant-earning pupil to an Indian residential school. Under these circumstances his admission cannot be approved.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Re: Archie & Mary Macquahway

The above named who state they are Treaty Indians under your jurisdiction (Ojibwe Band), were visitors at this Office yesterday inquiring as to the possibility of having two of their children admitted to the Fort William Indian Residential (Boarding) School. The two children they desire to have admitted are Doreen, age 11, and Kenneth, age 12.

Mr. Macquahway is presently a railway labourer in this area, and the family is living at Horns, Ont. (near Haith), and he advises there is no school in that vicinity where his children could attend school, and he is anxious for them to obtain at least a sound basic education. These two children have progressed thus far to grades II and IV, according to Mr. Macquahway's statement.

Would you kindly confirm as soon as possible that this family is on your Treaty Records and give any other pertinent details, so that we may be in a position to seek authority for their admittance to the Fort William Indian Residential School.

Yours truly,

J.G. Burk, Indian Agent.

Attention: Training Division

Mr. and Mrs. John Swanson (Long Sault #2 Band) have been into this office several times within the past month to interview me concerning having their three children discharged from the Fort William Indian Residential School. The names of these children and their ages are as undermentioned:

Irene - 15
Elizabeth - 14
Dorothy - 8

It will be noted that the Swanson's are members of the Long Sault Band, Fort Frances Agency, and as such, they do not actually come under my administration. However, they have been residing in Fort Arthur for some months, the exact time I have not yet been able to determine, or have been called upon in several instances, to deal with their problems. I endeavoured to obtain their admission to the Indian Residential School at Fort Frances, but was advised by the Indian Agent that there was no room in the school for them. These children have heretofore been attending a local separate school where they did not get along very well and in the summer the parents made up their mind that when the school term started in the fall, they would place them in a residential school and as a consequence, they were admitted to the Fort William school effective September 1st, 1946.

Realizing that any authority for a discharge must be received from you, I have not taken it upon myself to grant the parents request. However, considering this matter from many angles, I do not think it would be in the best interests of these three children to have them taken out of the residential school where they are reported by the Principal to be making good progress in their studies, eating better and improving their appearance and health generally. Upon enquiring around town, I learned that while the children were in attendance at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic School, their attendance at school was irregular, apparently being caused by both ill-health and parental neglect, and that they did not get along well with the white children and that their cleanliness left much to be desired at times. I further understand that St. Andrew's school would be reluctant to have them return to studies there. As far as the conditions in the Swanson home are concerned, I would advise that they are not very favourable for the children's welfare as I learned that there are constantly numerous Indians from outside around the house, keeping late hours and although I do not know this to be a fact personally, I hear there is a certain amount of drinking at times in their house. Mr. Swanson himself appears to be a very fine hardworking and steady worker and I am favourably impressed by him. Mrs. Swanson is, I would estimate, an average Indian woman and I have formed no particular opinion about her one way or the other.

As Mrs. Swanson said she will be back in the office around the 25th of November, to find out about the discharge of her children, if you would please review this matter and let me have
Indian Affairs Branch

Page 2

a decision by that date, it would be much appreciated.

J.G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

NP/TP

P.S. While it was reported in September that there was no room for these children at the residential school at Fort Frances, in a later communication from the Indian Agent of Fort Frances, I am informed that these children could now be admitted there. However, there seems little to be gained by transferring them from one residential school to another, unless it would make the parents feel happier that they are in a school under the administration of their own Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Information is requested regarding Indian pupils running away from Boarding School.

Three weeks ago, Percy Legarde, age 12, and John Wakates, age 11, left the playground of St. Joseph's Residential School and just recently have been located at Dog Lake. The local police in Port Arthur and Fort William were immediately contacted and were not able to locate the children. John Wakates' parents live at Dog Lake, some 40 or 50 miles northwest of Port Arthur and I was informed by a hunter that he had seen the two boys at the edge of Dog Lake. The only way of communicating with the Wakates boy's father, who is a trapper at Dog Lake, would be by dog team or plane, which would be very expensive. The Provincial police informed me it did not come under their jurisdiction.

In the meantime, an Indian trapper informed me that the boys finally got through to Wakates' father's camp, northwest of Dog Lake and they are now stopping at Little Dog River, some 65 miles northwest of Port Arthur. It would be extremely expensive to send a plane to this location; the plane will have to land and try to locate the cabin in the bush. If a dog team was sent in, it would cost considerable money.

Please advise what action I should take regarding the boys case, and also what steps should be taken in the case of future similar occurrences.

For Training Division,

The quarterly report, 30th June, for the Fort William Residential School, which was returned to this Agency has been re-checked and is now passed back to you herewith.

The general comment from you to the effect that there were 91 days in the quarter and the pupils are shown as in residence only for 87, 88, 89 and 90 days is noted. Please note that upon checking with Sister Carron she advises that the majority of the pupils departed the school on the 27th or 28th June for their holidays and were out of school for a matter of few days less than the whole quarter. She explained that this to her knowledge had been the custom in the past and expressed surprise at this particular observation. Perhaps you intend the school to take advantage of the full 91 days in future and not to deduct for the odd days missed at the end of June.

In going over the report she discovered two errors and there has been an adjustment accordingly.
